text: Hi, I saw a post about visiting smaller cities in Italy. I really enjoy local culture over crowded tourist spots. We are interested in the Amalfi Coast region for a trip next September. What cities would you recommend? Grazie 😊

comments.comment_text: Amalfi is super turistic.;) everyone in this group goes there
It’s a mob scene. Not culture, it’s beautiful, but not what you just described you are interested in.
For a smaller, village feel, go to Praiano, Maiori or Minori.

Very interesting post. Have you been to Italy before? When I think of culture over crowded tourist spots, the last place I think of is the Amalfi Coast. While there are smaller, quieter towns than Sorrento or Positano, I think of the Amalfi Coast as a resort area with the beach. If you want culture over tourist I would think of Bari, Tuscany, Sicily, or Emilio Romana regions/areas. Just my opinion.
We love the small towns in Tuscany, Emilia-Romano and Piedmonte. We immerse ourselves in the culture. The cities are beautiful for sure but not our focus

The Amalfi Coast is enormously popular for a reason. In peak season, yes, it is very busy. In the evening, many of the day trippers return to Sorrento, and it gets quieter. If you are going in September, I don't think you will experience the crowds many are describing. Honestly, all of the villages are wonderful. My favorite is Positano. Ravello is wonderful, too. If you are going to stay on the Amalfi Coast (instead of in Sorrento or, say, Capri), I personally suggest choosing a village with ferry service. If you want to take the ferry, you don't want to first have to take a bus or taxi to get to it.
Ravello is awesome and easy access to everything Amalfi.

Amalfi and Positano are much more beautiful in the evening when the boatloads of day tourists have gone. In the day you can skip the crowds and walk the path of the gods or visit minori or maiori or even walk the 20mins over to Atrani from Amalfi.

text: Euros. I did a search on this site, but didn't see anything on suggested increments? I assume you should take smaller bills for tipping and such. Is there a need to take larger increments? We will be using a cc for restaurants and larger purchases. Thanks.

comments.comment_text: Smaller is good
Get smaller bills not 100
Italian merchants love when you give them coins, in my experience. They seem to always need and welcome same.
I don’t even like to bring 50s! The smaller the better. And save your coins for the toilets or small tips.
Smaller bills are always better.
Many places won’t accept large bills because they don’t keep a lot of change, and there aren’t many places to change large bills. Banks will not do it.
5s & 10s with a few 20s thrown in there.

You should have coins for tipping. Coins come in increments as large as €2, and excluding maybe a tour guide, that’s a typical tip amount, if at all. Tipping isn’t the custom in Italy not because consumers are less generous, but rather because workers are better compensated.
Our hotel broke 50s when needed

A lot of their denominations for smaller bills are actually coins. Like $1 or 2. There isn’t much tipping as they have VAT on meals. If you’re using a Cc for means you’re fine. You’ll really be using cash for off the part spots like farmers markets etc where some thing may be cash only.

You can get them at an atm there. The exchange rate or fees is basically peanuts. Like .50 here or there depending on the day. It you so hit an ATM get like 2-300 at a time and don’t waste fees $20 yourself to death.
Take small bill, had large bills and had a hard time getting broke to smaller ones. Even went into a bank and the said, no change.
You don't need to tip...small amount of cash is good for markets & taxis.Euros for toilets.I used both.
Coins needed for some public restrooms!
Smart trick. When you take out money at the atm force it to give you 20ies. For instance 130 or 80. It will give you 50+4*20 and simply 4*20. However if you withdraw let’s say 200 it will be 4*50.
You need very little if any cash, use your CC.
In Tuscany & Umbria now. Small bills & 1 & 2 € coins a void thing. Must have for toilets- usually 1coin. Bottles of water usually 1
I just went to order mine at the bank. They said they can request small bills but not the increments I requested. They told me I Jane to just take what the exchange gives me.
Small bills. It’s basically tip and gelato money. 😄
You don't need to tip but 5 and 10 are the smallest bills or you cN use Coins. Not everyone breaks or accepts 100 eur bills
I exchanged 500€ in 5s, 10s, and a few 20s before traveling.
You tip with coins only. One or two euros per person max
5s and 10s and handfull of coins for tipping.

We went to banks and used their ATM's and were able to request smaller increments. Fees were very low when you used a bank Instead of an other ATM.... like 2$. We Requested 20s and did fine the entire time.

I work in a shop and we are happy with credit cards and coins but remember that not everyone in italy accept credit cards because they don’t want to pay taxes. Avoid those places and always ask if you can pay with card before buying anything. Groceries shops always accepts card payment and some of them don’t even have the cashier working during summer so only automatic register (but you can pay with cash on them as well)

Thanks for the information!

I purchased most my olive oil in cans. One came home dented but no leaks. I had glass jars of pistachio cream that I wrapped in clothing.

We used one half a suitcase for these purchases, padding with clothing and also wrapping in ziplock bags.

Our wine and Limoncello we split shipping with travel friends.
I always bring bubble wrap with me and the Built wine bags for bottles.
Where did you find pistachio cream?

I packed some bubble wrap for this reason and my parking cube set came with a waterproof bag and shoe bag I didn’t use for other items but I still packed them so I could put the wrapped bottles in them for the trip home - a little extra protection in case something broke.
There are inflate-able bubble wrap bottle protectors you can buy, they take up very little space until you inflate them.
Bubble wrap, there is bottle shaped bubble wrap also.
I use my clothes to wrap around the bottles and cushion with more clothes in between.
Pack it well, I had a bottle of Scotch break, my clothes were soaked & it ruined a new dress I bought 🙁

I bring bubble wrap with me. Package in 5hat then double plastic bag it.
Then I make sure the bottle is in the middle of the suitcase with nothing hard next to the bottle(S). So far no problems.

text:
I’ve worked sooo many hours figuring out our plan for my 40th for me and my husband. Beginning of September. 6 nights. We’re spending first and last night in Rome and the rest in Sorrento. Here’s our plan. Please tell me what you think! I am a mom of two little kids and I don’t stay up late or party much. 😆
-Depart US at 2:45. Take melatonin and try to sleep on the plane (hoping to fall asleep around 7pm Texas time. Will try to be falling asleep by 8pm a few nights before we leave).

Day 1
-Land in Rome 8:00am (1am to us), leave bags with hotel in piazza navona, go to a cafe/hang/explore. Go with rome time. No naps.
- do Heart of Rome walk around sunset, spend about 2 hours: Shop, visit pantheon, Jewish ghetto, end in campo di fiori for dinner. (Or maybe do it backwards and end for dinner at Spanish steps area?)

Day 2:
-prime experience Vatican tour with breakfast. (Already booked)
-Check out of hotel, board train to Naples, stop long enough to have pizza.
-private car pick up to take us to hotel de la ville. Check in, relax, explore Sorrento, beach maybe?

Day 3: Amalfi
- this is still very up in the air. I think we’ll ferry out to see the view of the coast from the water. Then start in amalfi/bus to Ravello, have lunch, hang out, explore. Car to positano. Hang out on the beach, have dinner. Private car home.

Day 4: capri
- sleep in, do whatever, shop, etc in Sorrento.
- capri night tour, departs at 3:30. Do the grottos, find a beach (which one?), have dinner and head home by 11:00. 😴
-considering ischia instead of capri 🤔

Day 5:
- no plan! Enjoy Sorrento.

Day 6: back to rome
- relax in the morning
- somehow get to pompei/Vesuvius on our way to rome via Naples since it’s on the way.
- no plan once we get to rome, maybe visit colosseum, a museum, not sure? Do a golf cart tour? 🤷🏼‍♀️
- dinner somewhere fun.
Stay at a hotel- haven’t decided what area yet for our last night. Maybe with a view of the colosseum?

Day 7: fly home
- flight leaves at 2pm, so take it easy morning, get bf, leave for hotel around 11am
- arrive at airport at 11:30am. Leaving us 2.5 hours to get to the plane.

Thank you!!

comments.comment_text: You would need another week to really explore these areas. I wouldn’t do this, but this may be all of the time you have and since you feel strongly about where you want to go, I wouldn’t want to dissuade you.
Book soon your last night in Rome as it is still very busy since Covid🌻

Ok you will most likely not sleep on a flight departing at 3pm. On arrival is when you'll be sleepy. Hope you can check in early, but if not, please take a nap for about 2 hours when you do check in. This nap will keep you going till 10-11pm. Otherwise you'll be falling asleep at 6/7pm and then waking up in the middle of the night wide awake and sleepy again in the morning when you should be going out. Save the melatonin or an otc sleep aid to take when you go to bed for the night to help you sleep through the entire night.
Also when you do take that nap...set your alarms several feet from the bed to force you to get up. It will be really hard initially however after an hour, a shower and cappuccino I promise you'll feel much better. This is the advice most people thank me for.

That’s an ambitious plan! There is so much to see and do in Rome. Just make sure you book your tix in advance for the Vatican. It’s nice to walk around and just enjoy the food and sites. I spent 4 days in Sorrento last summer and I loved it. Was my first time there and did half day trip to Pompeii on train. I booked a tour guide and they met you at the Sorrento train station. Easier to do that. Half a day out on Capri. It’s nice but expensive. Ferry ride to Positano on another day. Make sure to go early. I d didn’t and didn’t have much time there. Ferries don’t go that frequently. I would leave pizza in Naples out. I haven’t done it before and didn’t feel like I was missing a anything.

I would stay in Sorrento… Rent a Vespa and drive yourself up the Amalfi coast highway. My wife is terrified of motorbikes but her memory of that drive is the best of our trips to Italy. It’s safe and you can stop whenever you want. You can get a hovercraft from Sorrento to Capri. Sorrento is incredible and had one of the best hotels around. The Hotel Bellevue Syrene. You look straight down 1,000 feet to the water. Fantastic restaurant. A stay you will NEVER forget.

You mention “bf” twice. What does that stand for?

Day three sounds like a lot. I think the time it takes to ferry around, bus to Ravello to explore it won’t leave much time for Positano too. Might choose between the two spots.

Curious, you have rented a private car to drive you to Positano? Then it waits around for you and you get driven back to your home base in Sorrento? If so…may I ask how much this service is costing? (Or is it renting a car for two different car rides/two reservations) I am not interested in renting a car and driving that area so am interested in doing a private 🚙 too!😁

I have read Ischia is a more relaxed place to visit. (If you are looking for that type of experience) Capri is more fast paced (& more expensive) I thought I would want to do Capri but after much research, I am thinking my plan will be Ischia instead.

Day six is too packed. Travel takes more time than people think. Taking the train to Naples then on to Pompeii to explore then taking train on to Rome…you would not have much time for Rome that night. It would probably be more of just arriving, dinner, packing and sleeping. As others have suggested, you might consider skipping Pompeii in order to leave more time to explore Rome. (You will not regret it)

You might be able do your planned schedule. I of course am only one opinion. I am a fast paced person and thought I had left enough time in each of my destinations but after all was said and done, we needed more time in each spot to truly experience Italy. We are dying to go back but now know we need to plan less so we enjoy more! If that makes sense 😂 Wishing you a wonderful vacation! 🌺
Timeshifter app to help with jet lag.

It’s an ambitious itinerary. Keep your day 1 plans to a minimum and be prepared for an early dinner/early to bed since you will be sleep deprived. Day 6 seems unrealistic. You could spend an entire day at Pompei.
All great ideas but you’ll need to be realistic about what you can see and enjoy in the time you have.

Here’s my jet lag hack- Not sure if it’s an option from your US departure city but if I travel transatlantic flights from NYC I look for morning flights. I keep busy (usually working) the entire flight. You arrive later in the evening CET go have a light bight to eat and go to bed local time. Wake up the next day and you just beat the jet lag.

Try Virgin Atlantic
I think grotto closes at/before 5 ish

A new train service began in July between Rome and Pompei. Check this out. We also booked the same hotel in Sorrento for this October. Please give us your feedback.
You’re only 40! Do what you can and have fun!! 💐🥂

Increase your time away to 10-14 days if you can change your flights if you are seriously dead set on that itinerary. Unless you prove to be one of those very few people who can sleep anytime I would not imagine you will sleep at all on the plane at that time of day. So you will never last until sunset unless you are the sort that clubs all night and works all day in normal life. So nap as suggested above on check in or go to bed after an early dinner on first night. Pompeii - if you really want to see that you should start very early and go there and back first then to Rome getting luggage en route. I would scrap Pompeii and go to the Villa Borghese that afternoon and the Colosseum in the evening when you get back to Rome.

Breakneck pace, but I totally get wanting to fit in all the things you’ve been dreaming about. How about going to Pompeii for half a day on day 5 (Sorrento overnight)? There isn’t much to *do* in Sorrento in terms of specific sights or activities — it’s just a lovely place! — so this could be an idea to fill part of that unplanned day. Sorrento -> Pompeii -> Rome in a day is impossible. I used to lead tours down there - it’s more than you might think in terms of the travel time and general friction of train stations etc etc. I 💯 recommend Capri over Ischia for this particular trip as it’s just SO much more impressive. (I ❤️ Ischia, but it’s a different thing .. Capri gives you a THRILL.) Absolutely do the Blue Grotto. It’s touristy - and it’s FUN! For Rome, if your heart is set on going into the Colosseum, book skip the line tickets. Any other questions about Rome, I am happy to help - was a tour guide there for years! Have a great time!!!!

We just did a European vacation.... Landed what was 2am our time. Powered through until 2am home time which was 9pm Ireland time. We kept moving during the day and didn't oveat. It was worth it. The next day we had no jet lag as we slept the night away and woke up on Ireland time. reat. Good luck and have a great time

I think the Amalfi/ravello day may not have time for that AND positano - prob one or the other.
I don’t think you will have time for Pompeii.
I also think Rome is getting short changed.
It will still be very crowded in sept.

Your plan is very similar to mine!!! We do: Ravello daughter’s wedding!! There 6 days. Then Sorrento for 4 nights, Rome 3 nights, fly home Saturday morning! Doing the golf cart tour in Rome! Walking eating tour in sorrento, farm visit in sorrento.

Think what you are doing sounds great, but probably for someone who isn't going to get much rest or relaxation. Unless you are out of the hotel by 6am each day, you are not going to fit it all in easily.
I would suggest that you choose Positano OR Ravello as it's too much to try to do both in one day.
I don't understand all these people telling you to ditch Pompeii - it's absolutely amazing. Do it in the morning as a half day from Sorrento, perhaps on day 5, so you still have the afternoon to chill. The train takes you straight there, but make sure you are booked with a guided tour as it's not something you can easily do without one. Vesuvious is just a mountain that is a bit smokey at the top, nothing special and if you were to ditch anything, ditch that.

Whatever you do, relax and enjoy it, rather than try to tick things off a list. Certainly have a wish list but don't beat yourself up about it if you don't do everything on the list. There's always next time.

I flew in and out of Rome FCO last year. The airport is huge and we were told to allow 3 hours before departure from Rome before our flights. We needed every minute of those three hours, so don't cut it too close. Our flight out was in the early morning and we had to get a cab at 5:30 am when there is no traffic and only a half hour drive from Rome's center to the airport by the coast. You may need to leave more time on that last day if you want to make your departing afternoon flight. Also, trains in Naples area to and from Sorrento are tricky. The ticket office sold us tickets for the local train instead of the tourist train (which makes less stops). Pompeii, we were told, is vast and a short tour won't do it justice. We did Herculaneum tour instead with virtual reality glasses to see what things looked like before its population was essentially vaporized (unlike Pompeii that was buried in ash, so if you are more interested in seeing the results of being buried alive, Pompeii is your go-to). And If you are going to try to grab a pizza in Naples between disembarking from your train and getting picked up by your driver, have you thought what you will do with your luggage? I had the same dilemma and did not want to walk it to a locker a few blocks from the train station by myself while I explored for a couple of hours in Naples, so I missed out on pizza and spending time at the archeological museum there which houses many artifacts from the cities that Vesuvius destroyed. I would maybe leave a day or at least half a day to explore Naples if I get there again, which I hope to do someday. Sorrento is lovely and Franks Pizza has lines out the door and down the street if you want great pizza. What we saw of Capri was crowded and somewhat disappointing except for the panoramic views from on high and the ferry around the island. You can take the funicular up to the town when you get off the ferry for a couple of euros and skip the tours that nice little old men will try to scam you on (we fell for that when getting off the ferry from Sorrento to Capri.) Have a fabulous time! You have a lot planned for a short time and that is the problem with Italy--too much to see and love about it, and always too little time!

You should book a day trip to Pompeii on that day you have no plans. I used Get Your Guide and it came with train tickets; the guide meets you at the train station in Sorrento and you’re with him the whole way through. It was very worth it! You come back and still have time to do whatever else when you come back to Sorrento!
Sounds like an excellent trip filled with quality over quantity. The making of memories. It's refreshing to see someone not trying to cram in 7 cities in 7 days!
The whole point is to eat at the Jewish ghetto!! best food in Rome. Don't ear in the high tourist areas.
Way, way, way too much.
leave no later than 10am for the flight home!
I agree with the person who says to do Pompeii on day 5 and get to Rome earlier on Day 6.

We did this trip and more with a toddler. You can do it! We walked all over Rome in less than 48 hrs. We saw everything except Vatican City (we are already booked to see it 2024) Rome has amazing food and breathtaking sites… see as much as you can. We didn’t do any tours as it wastes a ton of time. Especially because you aren’t in Italy very long.
I would skip Capri it takes up a whole day … there’s too much to see on the coast. Taking a private yacht is a must. That was our favorite day.
We did Pompeii on the way to Amalfi. Our private driver kept our luggage in the car until we were done. I’m sure you can do that on your way back to Rome or on your way to Amalfi. Definitely get the pizza in Naples - it’s best pizza in the world. I still dream about it lol.
In Amalfi we walked everywhere. We found amazing beaches and food. Have fun! Oh yeah visiting Italy is not a vacation it’s see as much as you can and doing as much as you can until you’re so exhausted! But that’s living 😉

Definitely do Pompeii it's amazing. But make sure to get a guide so you know what you're looking at. We used Sorrento Food Tours. This included transportation,
a guided tour, then wine tasting and lunch at a winery. It was a great day trip.

Okay. First you will be exhausted when you get there, jet lag etc. Rest up, at least until the afternoon . There’s a lot in Rome to see. Do as much of it as you can before you leave for Sorrento. And when you get there, by train or bus, stay in the town, enjoy it, and take tours via Aviator etc from the port to Capri, Pompeii, Vesuvius.

And you can get to Positano from there by ferry. Don’t drive.
There's a very good museum under Piazza Navona (I notice your hotel is at Piazza Navona), it's not "dungeon" like but is under the square. We really enjoyed it!

Ok only read through day one in Rome and yes, push through, no naps. Helps adjust quickly to time zone. Campo di Fiori is a 8-12 noon for market place and then it folds up and is gone for the day. Spanish steps and geloto great end of day. IMO

left and you will see a kiosk where you buy tickets for the lift which takes you down to the port and ferries for Capri/Ischia. It saves you the long walk down and up again. Good luck. Enjoy and try and find time to stand and stare 🤣🍋

I think it sounds great. You can always adjust along the way if it seems like too much. Enjoy !!

comments.comment_text:
Regarding Monte Etna, wear sturdy shoes as volcanic soil can hurt you if not covered. The weather up on the mountain CAN change drastically in a matter of minutes. I had to wear a thick lined jacket as soon as the sun disappeared in the clouds in October morning. It is the easiest to approach from the south at Rifugio Sapienza. Take a funicular up and transfer to ATV (extra fee). We drove from our agriturismo in Santa Venerina via Zafferana Etnea.

As for train, Trenitalia’s official website/app and Italo’s official website/app are the best. Trenitalia probably works the best for your travel. If they have the same routes, compare the schedule and price
If you can, spend a day in Bologna on your way from Venice to Florence.
Perfect thanks I’m an experienced hiker but I’m looking for a guide still. So this helps much appreciated! Good to know the trains are not the best I will look into buses!
I’m taking train from Naples to Taormina. About 61/2 hrs. I want the experience and train to ferry experience as well. I didn’t think too bad.

For trains use Trenitalia and Italo apps /websites directly. No need to book 1st class only, especially on local trains. If you need more detailed info on trains just ask or dm.
I suggest one stop in Bologna for sure one of the best places to take a cooking class!

I have trained all over Italy. Works well for me & Palermo is a great place in Sicily , lots to do , take a train to a town called Cefalu about one hour from Palermo, y can’t get any close to the beach unless u were walking on the beach + another bus to a town called Mondello lovely beach & we were there in October, weather was great . If u drink white wine , it is beautiful around Mt. Etna to do with the soil around the volcano 🌻

Book trains directly with Trenitalia (or Italo if they service the route you want to take). Websites are easy to use. That's a big itinerary for a month so I hope you're not rushed. If you're looking for a private shuttle from to/from Napled/
Sorrento I highly recommend Transferelax. We based ourselves in Sorrento and did day trips to Capri and Positano. I've only driven in Sicily so can't comment on public transport there. Have a wonderful time in magical Italy.

text: Brand new to this site. Planning first trip to Italy. Would you recommend a guided tour of Italy or plan your own? If tour, which ones have you used?
